author: ralexstokes
content:
the intent of "warm COINBASE" is to reduce gas costs for _users_ of that address in a block -- as the others have said there is no gas model for PoW coinbase payments so this warm/cold distinction doesn't apply

And the same reasoning applies to the withdrawal recipients in a block after EIP-4895; clients could use this information to pre-fetch parts of the state or similar optimizations but there is no need to change the gas model/schedule

author: chfast
content: After some considerations, how about we mark tests for EOFv1 as `+EOFv1.0` so we can have space for `+EOFv1.1` milestone later (e.g. with `JUMPF`).

author: holiman
content: I agree with <@539495253418180618> and <@425274498732916736> - they should _not_ be considered warm just because  they _later_ will be loaded. Doing so would be introducing a very _quirky_ wart: adding (or not) an event (a withdrawal) at the end of the block affects all prior transaction executions. Let's not go there

author: holiman
content: It's not the "same" reason -- the block coinbase is part of the observable state.  If you change coinbase, then yes, you need to re-exec the txs. But the block withdrawals are not part of the observable state, but making then warm would (indirectly) make them so.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Allright, thanks for the reply ðŸ™‚ I wanted to raise this point to prevent possible future EIPs to "fix" these things later on like the warm coinbase (I think we mostly/all agree that this should be part of 2929?)

author: jochembrouwer
content: So dismiss my message. Thanks all ðŸ™‚
